sources.source_name: Committee of Land Valuation Experts in Lower Saxony (Oberer Gutachterausschuss für Grundstückswerte in Niedersachsen, OGA)
sources.description: The dataset consists of nearly all sale transactions of arable land in Lower Saxony between 1990 and 2018. It includes 72,547 sale transactions with details such as price, sold area, seller and buyer information, date of transaction, and allocation of the plot to a county. The data is used to analyze the spatial and temporal variability of land market liquidity in Lower Saxony, focusing on volume-based and time-based measures. The study also derived the volume duration, which is the number of days until a specific percentage of land per county was sold, focusing on 1% volume duration with robustness checks for 0.5% and 1.5%.
sources.access_conditions: provided by the Committee of Land Valuation Experts in Lower Saxony
paper_titles: Measuring liquidity in agricultural land markets
Farmland sales under returns and price uncertainty

source_papers: Farmland sales under returns and price uncertainty
Measuring liquidity in agricultural land markets

sources.source_name: Committee of Land Valuation Experts in Saxony-Anhalt and Lower Saxony
sources.description: The dataset includes agricultural land transactions in Saxony-Anhalt and Lower Saxony, Germany, from 1994 to 2017. It contains information on the price, size, soil quality, location, and type (arable land or grassland) of the transacted plot. Since 2011, information about the buyer (farmer or non-farmer) is also available. The dataset was used to analyze the relationship between land price and parcel size using a nonparametric locally weighted scatterplot smoothing (LOWESS) estimator and a hedonic land price model, as well as the spatial integration of land markets across the former East and West Germany border.
sources.access_conditions: Data provided by the Committee of Land Valuation Experts in Saxony-Anhalt and Lower Saxony
paper_titles: Revisiting the relationship between land price and parcel size in agriculture
Land price diffusion across borders – the case of Germany
paper_filenames: Land price diffusion across borders   the case of Germany.pdf

source_papers: Revisiting the relationship between land price and parcel size in agriculture

sources.source_name: Comprehensive Farmland Data Sources for Germany (2017-2022)
sources.description: This dataset combines multiple sources to provide a comprehensive view of farmland data in Germany. It includes remote sensing-based crop-type maps used to quantify woody features with a spatial resolution of 10 m, covering the years 2017 to 2019 in Brandenburg. Additionally, it incorporates data from the Common Breeding Bird Monitoring Scheme of Germany (CBBS), which assesses avian biodiversity through annual surveys on up to 1800 plots across Germany, filtered for approximately 200 survey plots in Brandenburg for the same years. Furthermore, it includes data from an economic experiment conducted in 2022 to simulate bargaining processes in the land rental market across various federal states in Germany, capturing rental rate offers and acceptance thresholds.
sources.access_conditions: Not publicly available; Data collected through a controlled experiment, not publicly accessible
paper_title: Multi-objective spatial optimization to balance trade-offs between farmland bird diversity and potential agricultural net returns
Experimental evidence of bargaining power in agricultural land markets

source_papers: Multi-objective spatial optimization to balance trade-offs between farmland bird diversity and potential agricultural net returns

sources.source_name: EU Integrated Administration and Control System (IACS)
sources.description: Plot-level data on agricultural parameters for the years 2017, 2018, and 2019. Used to derive cropland area, field sizes, crops grown, average distances of all fields of a farm relative to each other, and whether a farm was managed for organic or conventional agriculture.
sources.access_conditions: Not publicly available
sources.paper_title: Multi-objective spatial optimization to balance trade-offs between farmland bird diversity and potential agricultural net returns

source_papers: Multi-objective spatial optimization to balance trade-offs between farmland bird diversity and potential agricultural net returns

sources.description: The study uses data from the Integrated Administrative Control System (IACS) for Brandenburg, Germany, covering the years 2005 to 2017. This dataset includes all plots registered to receive European subsidies, based on a geo-referenced land parcel identification system. Each plot is associated with a farm registration number, indicating the farm operating the plot, regardless of the farmstead's location or whether the land is owned or rented. The dataset allows for a precise and spatially explicit analysis of farm activities, enabling the tracking of farm size development over time and the measurement of agricultural land concentration. The data shows that about half of the land transactions occur beyond municipality borders, highlighting the importance of defining the relevant market. The dataset reports a decrease in total agricultural area and the number of farms, alongside an increase in average farm size. It also records changes in farm registration numbers, indicating land transactions. The IACS data is used to derive concentration indicators and assess the impact of land market competition on farm expansion behavior.
sources.access_conditions: access granted by the Ministry for Agriculture, Environment and Climate Protection (MLUK) Brandenburg
sources.paper_title: Farm growth and land concentration

source_papers: Farm growth and land concentration

sources.description: The study uses a dataset of 9,754 first-price sealed-bid farmland privatisation auctions conducted in eastern Germany between 2007 and 2020. The data includes information on all bids and the auctioned goods, such as location, lot size, lot type (shares of arable, grassland, and other land), lot composition (number of parcels), and soil quality. Additionally, local experts' appraisals, which remain private to the auctioneer, are used to account for unobserved heterogeneity. These appraisals are based on publicly available results of transactions and auctions of similar lots in the same region during the 12 months prior to the auction. The dataset is used to test the presence of common values in bidders' valuations and the potential for a winner's curse in farmland auctions.
sources.access_conditions: Data provided by BVVG and not publicly available
sources.paper_title: Is there a risk of a winner’s curse in farmland auctions?

source_papers: Is there a risk of a winner’s curse in farmland auctions?

sources.source_name: GENESIS-Database of the German Bundesamt für Statistik
sources.description: The dataset contains aggregated farmland price time series from 1991 to 2020 within Germany. Prices are aggregated within soil quality intervals and parcel size intervals, treated as panel units. The dataset has a balanced panel structure with 145 observations and 870 price data points in total. The number of recorded transactions used to aggregate the farmland prices were collected manually from the Statistische Jahrbücher in Germany from 1991 to 2020. The minimum number of transactions recorded per SQI interval is 3,929, and the maximum is 15,819. The dataset helps maintain soil quality constant within the defined interval while depicting the farmland price development over time. Other variables are not available due to the levels of data aggregation, and regional prices are not captured.
sources.access_conditions: Free access
sources.paper_title: Revisiting the relationship between farmland prices and soil quality

source_papers: Revisiting the relationship between farmland prices and soil quality

sources.description: The study uses land sales transaction data from local committees of land valuation experts in Brandenburg, Germany, covering the years 2007 to 2018. This dataset includes transaction prices, lot sizes, soil quality, type of land use (arable land or grassland), and anonymized information about buyer and seller types. The data is used to analyze the relationship between land use concentration and farmland prices, revealing a negative relationship that suggests market power on the buyer side.
sources.access_conditions: Data is available from local committees of land valuation experts, but access may be restricted due to privacy concerns.
sources.paper_title: Market Power in Agricultural Land Markets: Concepts and Empirical Challenges

source_papers: Market Power in Agricultural Land Markets: Concepts and Empirical Challenges

sources.description: The study uses data from experiments conducted with the business game FarmAgriPoliS, which is based on the AgriPoliS model. This model simulates farms, regional farm populations, and structures, focusing on strategic decisions like farm exit or continuation, investments, and land rentals. The experiments involved 49 students managing pre-specified farms in a simulated environment representing the Altmark region in Germany. The dataset includes 143 experiments across nine scenarios, with data on farm investments, land rentals, farm sizes, financial results, and rents paid.
sources.access_conditions: Data was collected during controlled experiments and is not publicly available.
sources.paper_title: Predator or prey? Effects of farm growth on neighbouring farms
sources.paper_filename: J Agricultural Economics - 2022 - Appel - Predator or prey  Effects of farm growth on neighbouring farms.pdf

sources.source_name: Committee of Land Valuation Experts of Saxony-Anhalt
sources.description: The dataset consists of 12,134 land market transactions for arable land in Saxony-Anhalt from 2014 to 2017. It includes transaction details such as contract date, price, lot characteristics (location, size, soil quality index), and anonymous agent-type information. The data was used to analyze the role of asymmetric information in farmland price formation, focusing on the effects of buyer and seller characteristics on price dispersion.
sources.access_conditions: Provided by the Committee of Land Valuation Experts of Saxony-Anhalt
sources.paper_title: Price Dispersion in Farmland Markets: What is the Role of Asymmetric Information?
sources.paper_filename: American J Agri Economics - 2020 - Seifert - Price Dispersion in Farmland Markets  What Is the Role of Asymmetric.pdf

source_papers: Price Dispersion in Farmland Markets: What is the Role of Asymmetric Information?

sources.description: Land price data from 1975-2016 were extracted from the Statistisches Jahrbuch published by the Statistisches Bundesamt. Prices refer to agricultural land including arable land and grassland. Nominal agricultural land sales prices are available on country and federal state level on an annual basis. Land rental prices are also available at country and federal state level, but only for every second (1975-2007) or third year (after 2007) due to the frequency of the underlying Agricultural census. To conduct an analysis on a yearly basis, rental prices were linearly interpolated. The rental price data reflect prices of running contracts, i.e., they reflect the average of the rent paid for agricultural land during a contract period of several years. Rental price data for newly concluded contracts would have been more suitable for the analysis since they reflect the most recent information about expected productivity of land, but unfortunately, these data are not available for the desired time period. This implies that rental prices in the analysis appear more sluggish than they actually are. To conduct the analysis for Western Germany as a whole, federal state data on land sales and rental prices were used and averaged using the agricultural area of every federal state as weights. Nominal prices were converted into real prices by measuring inflation with the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for Germany published by Statistisches Bundesamt.
sources.access_conditions: available online
sources.paper_title: What Moves the German Land Market? A Decomposition of the Land Rent-Price Ratio

source_papers: What Moves the German Land Market? A Decomposition of the Land Rent-Price Ratio

sources.description: The dataset consists of over 12,000 first-price-sealed-bid auctions of agricultural land conducted by BVVG in Eastern Germany between 2005 and 2019. The data includes information on the winning bid, the total number of bidders, the exact date of the auction, the location, plot-specific land characteristics including a soil quality index, the lot size, the number of land parcels, and the type of use (arable land versus pasture), as well as the type of tender (open versus restricted). The data was used to analyze the effectiveness of restricted tendering procedures in allowing structurally disadvantaged groups to purchase agricultural land at lower prices. The study found that restricted tendering did not achieve its intended purpose of lowering purchase prices, although it did reduce the number of bidders.
sources.access_conditions: provided by BVVG
sources.paper_title: On the effectiveness of restricted tendering as a form of policy intervention on agricultural land markets

sources.description: The dataset used by RHOS for the original study, covering land transactions in Saxony-Anhalt from 1994 to 2017. It includes information on price, plot size, soil quality, and buyer type. The data was used to study the size–price relationship of farmland using a nonparametric smoothing estimator and a hedonic land price model.

sources.description: The dataset includes information on arable land auctions conducted by the BVVG in eastern German states from 2005 to 2019. It contains details on auction packages (lots), which may include one or more plots, and for each sale transaction, the date, number of bidders, and all bids are recorded. Additionally, information on plot size, number of plots, and soil quality is provided. The dataset was used to analyze the potential for increasing revenues through optimal reserve prices in land auctions.
sources.access_conditions: Data collected by BVVG, not publicly available

sources.description: The dataset includes all BVVG auctions from January 3, 2007, to July 17, 2015, covering all Eastern Federal States of Germany. It contains information on winning bids, total number of bidders, auction dates, locations, plot-specific land characteristics (including a soil quality index), lot size, number of parcels, and type of usage. It also includes bidder characteristics such as legal status, former tenant status, and foreign involvement.

This data was originally collected for the purposes of the German Federal Building Code and was used to calculate local averages of land sales prices.

sources.source_name: Committee of Evaluation Experts in Lower Saxony (Oberer Gutachterausschuss für Grundstückswerte in Niedersachsen)
sources.description: The dataset consists of records of individual land sale transactions for arable land in Lower Saxony, Germany, from January 1985 to December 2015. It includes the price of each sold lot, soil quality as a yield index, and the size of the lot in square meters. This data was used to build a balanced panel of quarterly average county prices, adjusted for soil quality and plot size using a hedonic regression model.
sources.access_conditions: Data provided by the committee of evaluation experts in Lower Saxony
sources.paper_title: The Spatial and Temporal Diffusion of Agricultural Land Prices

source_papers: The Spatial and Temporal Diffusion of Agricultural Land Prices

sources.description: The study used spatially explicit land cover data from the Integrated Administration and Control System (IACS) to describe landscape composition and configuration. The data was used to define four ecosystem function indicators: the Shannon diversity index, edge density, and shares of grassland and ecological focus areas. The IACS data provided spatially explicit information at the plot level of registered plots above the minimum eligible size of 0.3 ha, including location, shape, land use, crop choice, and ecological focus areas.
sources.access_conditions: Available through the EU’s Common Agricultural Policy (CAP)
sources.paper_title: Eco-efficiency in the agricultural landscape of North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany

source_papers: Eco-efficiency in the agricultural landscape of North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany

sources.description: Standardized farmland values were used to indicate the economic output of the landscape. These values are provided by local land valuation expert committees and refer to a standardized lot reflecting local characteristics such as soil quality and lot sizes. The values are based on land transactions in the same land value zone in the two years prior to the reporting year, adjusted for local average conditions and a rectangular shape.
sources.access_conditions: Available through local land valuation expert committees

source_papers: Eco-efficiency in the agricultural landscape of North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany

sources.description: The study revisits public preferences for pasture landscapes in Germany, focusing on the presence of livestock in the landscape. It uses a Discrete Choice Experiment (DCE) to assess preferences for different landscape attributes, including the presence and number of dairy livestock, structuredness of the pasture, point landscape elements, linear landscape elements, and cost per household per year. The DCE was part of an online survey conducted in Germany with 475 participants, of which 449 were included in the study sample. The survey ensured representativeness concerning age, household income, federal state of residence, and size of the place of residence. The data was collected by an online-sampling company in September and October of 2017.
sources.access_conditions: Not specified
sources.paper_title: Public Preferences for Pasture Landscapes and the Role of Scale Heterogeneity

source_papers: Public Preferences for Pasture Landscapes and the Role of Scale Heterogeneity
